<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>*</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>American
Airlines aircraft totals include 27 Boeing 757-200s and 103 McDonnell Douglas MD-80s that were formerly TWA aircraft </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the following owned and leased aircraft were not operated by the Company as of December&nbsp;31, 2002: seven owned Boeing
727-200s, 14 operating leased Boeing 717-200s, 11 operating leased McDonnell Douglas DC-9s, six owned McDonnell Douglas DC-10-10s, four
operating leased McDonnell Douglas MD-80s, eight operating leased Boeing 767-300s, six owned Embraer 145s and 16 capital leased and two owned Saab 340Bs. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of
the non-operating aircraft discussed above, five McDonnell Douglas DC-10-10 aircraft were being leased to Hawaiian Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. (Hawaiian)
as of December&nbsp;31, 2002 and six Embraer 145 aircraft are currently being leased to Trans States Airlines (Trans States). Upon termination of the lease agreement with Hawaiian, the Company has
agreed to sell the remaining six McDonnell Douglas DC10-10 aircraft to FedEx Corporation in 2003. In addition, Trans States has agreed to acquire a total of 14 Embraer 145 aircraft from
the Company, including the six non-operating Embraer 145s discussed above, in 2003. The Company is actively marketing its remaining non-operating aircraft and does not
anticipate bringing these aircraft back into its operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of
the operating aircraft in the above table, 28 McDonnell Douglas MD-80s, eight Boeing 767-200s and six Boeing 767-200ERs will be placed in temporary
storage beginning in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
information concerning the estimated useful lives and residual values for owned aircraft, lease terms for leased aircraft and amortization relating to aircraft under capital leases,
see Notes 1 and 7 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>16</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially
all of the Company's aircraft leases include an option to purchase the aircraft or to extend the lease term, or both, with the purchase price or renewal rental to be based
essentially on the market value of the aircraft at the end of the term of the lease or at a predetermined fixed amount. The Company does not intend to purchase or extend the lease term on any aircraft
with lease expirations in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Ground Properties</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases, or has built as leasehold improvements on leased property, most of its airport and terminal facilities; maintenance and training facilities in
Fort Worth, Texas; its principal overhaul and maintenance bases at Tulsa International Airport (Tulsa, Oklahoma), Kansas City International Airport (Kansas City, Missouri) and Alliance Airport (Fort
Worth, Texas); its regional reservation offices; and local ticket and administration offices throughout the system. American has entered into agreements with the Tulsa Municipal Airport Trust; the
Alliance Airport Authority, Fort Worth, Texas; the New York City Industrial Development Agency; and the Dallas/Fort Worth, Chicago O'Hare, Newark, San Juan, and Los Angeles airport authorities to
provide funds for constructing, improving and modifying facilities and acquiring equipment which are or will be leased to the Company. The Company also uses public airports for its flight operations
under lease or use arrangements with the municipalities or governmental agencies owning or controlling them and leases certain other ground equipment for use at its facilities. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
information concerning the estimated lives and residual values for owned ground properties, lease terms and amortization relating to ground properties under capital leases, and
acquisitions of ground properties, see Notes 1 and 7 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>17</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=17,SEQ=18,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=734095,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DE1349C.;7',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;19:39' -->
<A NAME="page_de1349_1_18"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;26, 1999, a class action lawsuit was filed, and in November&nbsp;1999 an amended complaint was filed, against AMR Corporation, American
Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., AMR Eagle Holding Corporation, Airlines Reporting Corporation, and the Sabre Group Holdings,&nbsp;Inc. in the United States District Court for the Central District of
California, Western Division (<U>Westways World Travel,&nbsp;Inc. v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>). The lawsuit alleges that requiring travel agencies to pay debit memos to American
for violations of American's fare rules (by customers of the agencies): (1)&nbsp;breaches the Agent Reporting Agreement between American and AMR Eagle and the plaintiffs; (2)&nbsp;constitutes
unjust enrichment; and (3)&nbsp;violates the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act of 1970 (RICO). The as yet uncertified class includes all travel agencies who have been or will be
required to pay money to American for debit memos for fare rules&nbsp;violations from July&nbsp;26, 1995 to the present. The plaintiffs seek to enjoin American from enforcing the pricing rules in
question and to recover the amounts paid for debit memos, plus treble damages, attorneys' fees, and costs. The Company intends to vigorously defend the lawsuit. A final adverse court decision could
impose restrictions on the Company's relationships with travel agencies which, restrictions could have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;13, 1999, the United States (through the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice) sued AMR Corporation, American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., and AMR Eagle Holding
Corporation in federal court in Wichita, Kansas (<U>United States v. AMR Corporation, et al, No.&nbsp;99-1180-JTM, United States District Court for the District of
Kansas</U>). The lawsuit alleges that American unlawfully monopolized or attempted to monopolize airline passenger service to and from Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) by
increasing service when new competitors began flying to DFW, and by matching these new competitors' fares. The Department of Justice seeks to enjoin American from engaging in the alleged improper
conduct and to impose restraints on American to remedy the alleged effects of its past conduct. On April&nbsp;27, 2001, the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas granted American's motion
for summary judgment. On June&nbsp;26, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice appealed the granting of American's motion for summary judgment (<U>United States v.
AMR Corporation, et al, No.&nbsp;01-3203, United States District Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit</U>), and on September&nbsp;23, 2002, the parties presented oral
arguments to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals, which has not yet issued its decision. The Company intends to defend the lawsuit vigorously. A final adverse court decision imposing restrictions on the
Company's ability to respond to competitors would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Between
May&nbsp;14, 1999 and June&nbsp;7, 1999, seven class action lawsuits were filed against AMR Corporation, American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., and AMR Eagle Holding Corporation in
the United States District Court in Wichita, Kansas seeking treble damages under federal and state antitrust laws, as well as injunctive relief and attorneys' fees (<U>King v. AMR Corp., et
al.</U>; <U>Smith v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>; <U>Team Electric v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>; <U>Warren v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>;
<U>Whittier v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>; <U>Wright v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>; and <U>Youngdahl v. AMR Corp., et al.</U>). Collectively,
these lawsuits allege that American unlawfully monopolized or attempted to monopolize airline passenger service to and from DFW by increasing service when new competitors began flying to DFW, and by
matching these new competitors' fares. Two of the suits (<U>Smith</U> and <U>Wright</U>) also allege that American unlawfully monopolized or attempted to
monopolize airline passenger service to and from DFW by offering discounted fares to corporate purchasers, by offering a frequent flyer program, by imposing certain conditions on the use and
availability of certain fares, and by offering override commissions to travel agents. The suits propose to certify several classes of consumers, the broadest of which is all persons who purchased
tickets for air travel on American into or out of DFW from 1995 to the present. On November&nbsp;10, 1999, the District Court stayed all of these actions pending developments in the case brought by
the Department of Justice (see above description). As a result, to date no class has been certified. The Company intends to defend these lawsuits vigorously. One or more final adverse court decisions
imposing restrictions on the Company's ability to respond to competitors or awarding substantial money damages would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=18,SEQ=19,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=734933,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DE1349C.;7',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;19:39' -->
<A NAME="page_de1349_1_19"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;17, 2002, the named plaintiffs in <U>Hall, et al. v. United Airlines, et al.</U>, pending in the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of North Carolina, filed an amended complaint alleging that between 1995 and the present, American and over 15 other defendant airlines conspired to reduce commissions paid to U.S.-based travel agents
in violation of Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act. The court granted class action certification to the plaintiff on September&nbsp;17, 2002, defining the plaintiff class as all travel agents in
the United States, Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin Islands, who, at any time from October&nbsp;1, 1997 to the present, issued tickets, miscellaneous change orders, or prepaid ticket
advices for travel on any of the defendant airlines. The case is stayed as to US Airways and United Air Lines, since they filed for bankruptcy. American is vigorously defending the lawsuit. Defendant
carriers filed a motion for summary judgment on December&nbsp;10, 2002. Trial is set for September 02, 2003. A final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages or placing restrictions
on the Company's commission policies or practices would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;26, 2002, six travel agencies filed <U>Albany Travel Co., et al. v. Orbitz, LLC, et al.</U>, in the United States District Court for the Central
District of California against American, United Air Lines, Delta Air Lines, and Orbitz, LLC, alleging that American and the other defendants: (i)&nbsp;conspired to prevent travel agents from acting
as effective competitors in the distribution of airline tickets to passengers in violation of Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act; and (ii)&nbsp;conspired to monopolize the distribution of common
carrier air travel between airports in the United States in violation of Section&nbsp;2 of the Sherman Act. The named plaintiffs seek to certify a nationwide class of travel agents, but no class has
yet been certified. American is vigorously defending the lawsuit. On November&nbsp;25, 2002, the District Court stayed this case pending a judgment in Hall et. al. v. United Airlines, et. al. (see
above description). A final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages or placing restrictions on the Company's distribution practices would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;25, 2002, a collection of 38 Quebec travel agencies filed <U>Voyages Montambault (1989),&nbsp;Inc. v. International Air Transport Association,
et&nbsp;al.</U>, seeking a declaratory judgment of the Superior Court in Montreal, Canada that American and the other airline defendants owe a "fair and reasonable commission" to the
agencies, and that American and the other airline defendants breached alleged contracts with these agencies by adopting policies of not paying base commissions. The defendants are the International
Air Transport Association, the Air Transport Association, Air Canada, American, America West, Delta Air Lines, Grupo TACA, Northwest Airlines/KLM Airlines, United Air Lines, US Airways, and
Continental Airlines. American is vigorously defending the lawsuit. A final adverse court decision granting declaratory relief could expose the Company to claims for substantial money damages or force
the Company to pay agency commissions, either of which would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;13, 2002, the named plaintiffs in <U>Always Travel, et. al. v. Air Canada, et.&nbsp;al.</U>, pending in the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division,
Montreal, filed a statement of claim alleging that between 1995 and the present, American, the other defendant airlines, and the International Air Transport Association conspired to reduce commissions
paid to Canada-based travel agents in violation of Section&nbsp;45 of the Competition Act of Canada. The named plaintiffs seek to certify a nationwide class of travel agents. Plaintiffs' motion for
certification is set for hearing on September&nbsp;2, 2003. American is vigorously defending the lawsuit. A final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages or placing restrictions on
the Company's commission policies would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
August&nbsp;14, 2002, a class action lawsuit was filed against American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Western
Division (<U>All World Professional Travel Services,&nbsp;Inc. v. American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.</U>). The lawsuit alleges that requiring travel agencies to pay debit memos for
refunding tickets after September&nbsp;11, 2001: (1)&nbsp;breaches the Agent Reporting Agreement between American and plaintiff; (2)&nbsp;constitutes unjust enrichment; and (3)&nbsp;violates
the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act of 1970 (RICO). The as yet uncertified class includes all travel agencies who have or will be required to pay moneys to American for an
"administrative service charge," "penalty fee," or other fee for processing refunds on behalf of passengers who were unable to use their tickets in the days immediately following the resumption of air
carrier service after tragedies on September&nbsp;11, 2001. The plaintiff seeks to enjoin American from collecting the debit memos and to recover the amounts paid for the debit memos, plus treble
damages, attorneys' fees, and costs. The Company intends to vigorously defend the lawsuit. Although the Company believes that the litigation is without merit, an adverse court decision could impose
restrictions on the Company's relationships with travel agencies which restrictions could have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=19,SEQ=20,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=211498,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DE1349C.;7',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;19:39' -->
<A NAME="page_de1349_1_20"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
August&nbsp;19, 2002, a U.S. travel agency filed <U>Power Travel International,&nbsp;Inc. v. American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., et al.</U>, in New York state
court against American, Continental Airlines, Delta Air Lines, JetBlue Airways, United Air Lines, and Northwest Airlines, alleging that American and the other defendants breached their contracts with
the agency as well as the duty of good faith and fair dealing when these carriers at various times reduced base commissions to zero. The plaintiff seeks to certify a nationwide class of travel agents,
but no class has yet been certified. The plaintiff dismissed JetBlue from the lawsuit, and the remaining defendants removed the lawsuit to the United States District Court for the Southern District of
New York. The case is stayed as to United Air Lines, since it filed for bankruptcy. American is vigorously defending the lawsuit, and has filed a motion to dismiss it. A final adverse court decision
awarding substantial money damages or forcing the Company to pay agency commissions would have an adverse impact on the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Miami-Dade
County (the County) is currently investigating and remediating various environmental conditions at the Miami International Airport (MIA) and funding the
remediation costs through landing fees and various cost recovery methods. American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. and AMR Eagle have been named as potentially responsible parties (PRPs) for the contamination
at MIA. During the second quarter of 2001, the County filed a lawsuit against 17 defendants, including American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., in an attempt to recover its past and future cleanup costs
(<U>Miami-Dade County, Florida v. Advance Cargo Services,&nbsp;Inc., et&nbsp;al.</U> in the Florida Circuit Court). In addition to the 17 defendants named in the
lawsuit, 243 other agencies and companies were also named as PRPs and contributors to the contamination. American's and AMR Eagle's portion of the cleanup costs cannot be reasonably estimated due to
various factors, including the unknown extent of the remedial actions that may be required, the proportion of the cost that will ultimately be recovered from the responsible parties, and uncertainties
regarding the environmental agencies that will ultimately supervise the remedial activities and the nature of that supervision. The Company is vigorously defending the lawsuit. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=20,SEQ=21,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=304546,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DE1349C.;7',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;19:39' -->
<A NAME="page_de1349_1_21"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No matters were submitted to a vote of the Company's security holders during the last quarter of its fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT'S COMMON STOCK AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS  </B></FONT></P>

March&nbsp;31, 2003 was 13,000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March&nbsp;2003, Standard and Poor's removed AMR's common stock from the S&amp;P 500 index. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
after the close of business on March&nbsp;15, 2000, AMR distributed 0.722652 shares of Sabre Holdings Corporation (Sabre) Class&nbsp;A Common Stock for each share of AMR
stock owned by AMR's shareholders, thus distributing its entire ownership interest in Sabre. As such, Sabre has been treated as a discontinued operation in Item 6&#151;Selected Consolidated
Financial Data, Item 7&#151;Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and Item 8&#151;Consolidated Financial Statements. In addition, the
discussion in the other items of this Form&nbsp;10-K relates primarily to American and AMR Eagle. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No
cash dividends on common stock were declared for any period during 2002 or 2001. Payment of dividends is subject to various restrictions described in Note&nbsp;8 to the consolidated
financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=24,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=269500,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_24"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Equity Compensation Plan Information</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="34%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="20%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Number of securities to<BR>
be issued upon exercise<BR>
of outstanding options,<BR>
warrants and rights</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>

2,624,863 shares available for future grant under the 1998 Long Term Incentive Plan, as amended, 1,230,104 shares of deferred stock available for issue under the Performance
Share Program, 3,596,508 shares of deferred stock available for issue under the Career Equity Program and 451,534 shares available for issue under the 1994 Stock Incentive Plan for Directors (see
Note&nbsp;11 to the consolidated financial statements for more information) </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>***</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
March&nbsp;2003, the Compensation Committee of the AMR Board of Directors adopted the 2003 Employee Stock Incentive Plan to provide equity awards to employees in return for wage,
benefit and work rule concessions. Awards will be granted only after the Labor Agreements are ratified. (see Exhibit&nbsp;10.31 for a copy of this plan and Part&nbsp;A of Item 1 for a more
complete discussion of the Labor Agreements). </FONT></DD></DL>

<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
special charges and U.S. Government grant. For a further discussion of these items, see Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
a one-time, non-cash charge, effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, of $988&nbsp;million, net of tax, to write-off all of AMR's goodwill. This
charge resulted from the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards Board No.&nbsp;142, "Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets" and is reflected as a cumulative effect of accounting
change in the consolidated financial statements. For a further discussion of this item, see Note&nbsp;4 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;9, 2001, American (through its wholly owned subsidiary TWA Airlines LLC) purchased substantially all of the assets and assumed certain liabilities of Trans World
Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. (TWA). Accordingly, the 2001 financial information above includes the operating results of TWA LLC since the date of acquisition. See a further discussion of the TWA acquisition
in Note&nbsp;17 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
asset impairment charges, the impact of the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks and U.S. Government grant. For a further discussion of these items, see Note&nbsp;3 to
the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Restated
to reflect discontinued operations. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>6</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
earnings per share amounts reflect the stock split on June&nbsp;9, 1998. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>7</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company recorded an additional minimum pension liability adjustment resulting in an after tax charge to stockholders' equity of approximately
$1.0&nbsp;billion. Effective after the close of business on March&nbsp;15, 2000, AMR distributed 0.722652 shares of Sabre Holdings Corporation (Sabre) Class&nbsp;A Common Stock for each share of
AMR stock owned by AMR's shareholders, thus distributing its entire ownership interest in Sabre. The dividend of AMR's entire ownership in Sabre's common stock resulted in a reduction to AMR's
retained earnings equal to the carrying value of the Company's investment in Sabre on March&nbsp;15, 2000, which approximated $581&nbsp;million.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No
cash dividends were declared on AMR's common shares during any of the periods above. </FONT></P>

on the comparability of results is included in Management's Discussion and Analysis and the notes to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=27,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=40008,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_27"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AMR Corporation (AMR or the Company) was incorporated in October&nbsp;1982. AMR's principal subsidiary, American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., was founded in 1934. On
April&nbsp;9, 2001, Trans World Airlines LLC (TWA LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.) purchased substantially all of the assets and assumed certain liabilities of Trans
World Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. (TWA). Accordingly, the operating results of TWA LLC are included in the accompanying condensed consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002 whereas for 2001 the results of TWA LLC are included only for the period April&nbsp;10, 2001 through December&nbsp;31, 2001. All references to American Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. include the
operations of TWA LLC since April&nbsp;10, 2001 (collectively, American) (see Note&nbsp;17 to the consolidated financial statements). American is the largest scheduled passenger airline in the
world. In addition, AMR Eagle Holding Corporation (AMR Eagle), a wholly owned subsidiary of AMR, owns two regional airlines which do business as "American Eagle". AMR's operations fall almost entirely
in the airline industry. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Results of Operations</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AMR's net loss in 2002 was $3.5&nbsp;billion, or $22.57 per share. AMR's net loss in 2001 was $1.8&nbsp;billion, or $11.43 per share. The Company's 2002
results include a one-time, non-cash charge to record the cumulative effect of a change in accounting, effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, of $988&nbsp;million, or $6.35 per
share, to write-off all of AMR's goodwill upon the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards Board No.&nbsp;142 "Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets" (see Note&nbsp;4 to
the consolidated financial statements). The Company's 2002 results were adversely impacted by the continued economic slowdown and the residual effects of the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist
attacks as discussed in Part&nbsp;A of Item 1. For a discussion of the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001, see Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>REVENUES  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2002 Compared to 2001</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although traffic has continued to increase on reduced capacity since the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001, the
Company's 2002 revenues and yields were down materially year-over-year. In addition to the residual effects of September&nbsp;11, the Company's revenues continue to be
negatively impacted by the economic slowdown, seen largely in business travel declines and changes in business traveler profiles; the geographic distribution of the Company's network; and reduced
fares due in part to increased competition from low-cost carriers. The Company's revenues decreased approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion, or 8.8&nbsp;percent, to $17.3&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;American's
passenger revenues decreased by 8.5&nbsp;percent, or $1.3&nbsp;billion, to $14.4&nbsp;billion. System wide, passenger revenue yield per passenger mile decreased by
9.3&nbsp;percent, or 1.22 cents, to 11.86 cents, driving American's revenue per available seat mile (RASM) down by 7.2&nbsp;percent, or .65 cents, to 8.39 cents. In 2002, American derived
approximately 70&nbsp;percent of its passenger revenues from domestic operations and approximately 30&nbsp;percent from international operations. American's domestic RASM decreased
8.8&nbsp;percent, to 8.26 cents, on a capacity decrease of 1&nbsp;percent to 125&nbsp;billion available seat miles (ASMs). International RASM decreased to 8.72 cents, or 2.8&nbsp;percent, on a
capacity decrease of 7.2&nbsp;percent to 47&nbsp;billion ASMs.&nbsp;The decrease in international RASM was due to a 7.1&nbsp;percent decrease in Latin American RASM, somewhat offset by a
6.5&nbsp;percent and 0.3&nbsp;percent increase in Pacific and European RASM, respectively. The decrease in international capacity was due to a 22.4&nbsp;percent, 7.9&nbsp;percent and
3.3&nbsp;percent reduction in Pacific, European and Latin American ASMs, respectively. AMR Eagle's passenger revenues decreased $46&nbsp;million, or 3.3&nbsp;percent, to $1.3&nbsp;billion. AMR
Eagle's traffic increased 11&nbsp;percent, or 409&nbsp;million revenue passenger miles (RPMs), to 4.1&nbsp;billion RPMs, while capacity increased 1.9&nbsp;percent, or 121&nbsp;million ASMs,
to 6.6&nbsp;billion ASMs.&nbsp;Similar to American, the decrease in AMR Eagle's revenues was due primarily to the continued impact of the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks and the
economic slowdown. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues decreased 15.3&nbsp;percent, or $101&nbsp;million, to $561&nbsp;million primarily due to the economic slowdown and significant restrictions on cargo shipments for
security reasons. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenues decreased 15.5&nbsp;percent, or $177&nbsp;million, to $966&nbsp;million due primarily to decreases in contract maintenance work that American performs for other
airlines, and decreases in codeshare revenue and employee travel service charges. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=28,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=744105,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_28"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2001 Compared to 2000</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's 2001 revenues, yield, RPMs&nbsp;and ASMs&nbsp;were severely impacted by the September&nbsp;11,
2001 terrorist attacks, the Company's reduced operating schedule, a worsening of the U.S. economy that had already been dampening the demand for travel both domestically and internationally prior to
the September&nbsp;11, 2001 events, business travel declines as a result of the September&nbsp;11, 2001 attacks, and increased fare sale activity occurring subsequent to the September&nbsp;11
attacks to encourage passengers to resume flying. The Company's revenues decreased approximately $740&nbsp;million, or 3.8&nbsp;percent, versus 2000. However, excluding TWA LLC's revenues for the
period April&nbsp;10, 2001 through December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company's revenues would have decreased approximately $2.6&nbsp;billion versus 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
comparability purposes, the following discussion does not combine American's and TWA's results of operations or related statistics for 2001. American's passenger revenues decreased
by 14&nbsp;percent, or $2.3&nbsp;billion. In 2001, American derived approximately 68&nbsp;percent of its passenger revenues from domestic operations and approximately 32&nbsp;percent from
international operations. American's domestic RASM
decreased 11.3&nbsp;percent, to 9.28 cents, on a capacity decrease of 5&nbsp;percent to 104&nbsp;billion ASMs.&nbsp;International RASM decreased to 9.07 cents, or 5.2&nbsp;percent, on a
capacity decrease of 4.9&nbsp;percent. The decrease in international RASM was led by an 11.8&nbsp;percent and 10.8&nbsp;percent decrease in Pacific and European RASM, respectively, slightly
offset by a 0.9&nbsp;percent increase in Latin American RASM. The decrease in international capacity was driven by a 6.5&nbsp;percent and 4.7&nbsp;percent reduction in Latin American and
European ASMs, respectively, partially offset by an increase in Pacific capacity of 2.8&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;TWA
LLC's passenger revenues were approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion for the period April&nbsp;10, 2001 through December&nbsp;31, 2001. TWA LLC's RASM was 7.74 cents on capacity of
21.7&nbsp;billion ASMs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AMR
Eagle's passenger revenues decreased $74&nbsp;million, or 5.1&nbsp;percent. AMR Eagle's traffic remained flat compared to 2000, at 3.7&nbsp;billion RPMs, while capacity
increased to 6.5&nbsp;billion ASMs, or 3.4&nbsp;percent. Similar to American, the decrease in AMR Eagle's revenues was due primarily to the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks and a
worsening of the U.S. economy that had already been dampening the demand for air travel prior to the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues decreased 8.2&nbsp;percent, or $59&nbsp;million, for the same reasons as noted above. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=29,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=924566,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_29"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>OPERATING EXPENSES  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2002 Compared to 2001</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's operating expenses decreased 3.8&nbsp;percent, or $804&nbsp;million, to $20.6&nbsp;billion.
American's operating expenses per ASM decreased 1.5&nbsp;percent to 11.14 cents, including the impact of special charges and U.S. Government grant of $625&nbsp;million and $10&nbsp;million,
respectively, in 2002 and $1.2&nbsp;billion and $827&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2001. The decrease in operating expenses and operating expenses per ASM is largely due to cost savings
initiatives implemented in late 2001 and 2002. Wages, salaries and benefits increased 4.5&nbsp;percent, or $360&nbsp;million, to $8.4&nbsp;billion, reflecting (i)&nbsp;higher salaries, largely
offset by a decrease in the average number of equivalent employees and (ii)&nbsp;increases in the Company's pension and health insurance costs, the latter reflecting rapidly rising medical care and
prescription drug costs. Aircraft fuel expense decreased 11.3&nbsp;percent, or $326&nbsp;million, to $2.6&nbsp;billion, primarily due to a 3.3&nbsp;percent decrease in the Company's fuel
consumption and a 6.4&nbsp;percent decrease in the Company's average price per gallon. Depreciation and amortization decreased $38&nbsp;million, or 2.7&nbsp;percent, to $1.4&nbsp;billion due
primarily to discontinuing amortization of goodwill and route acquisition costs in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, "Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets".
Commissions, booking fees and credit card expense decreased 25.4&nbsp;percent, or $384&nbsp;million, to $1.1&nbsp;billion, due primarily to an 8.1&nbsp;percent decrease in passenger revenues
and commission structure changes implemented in March&nbsp;2002. Food service decreased 10.3&nbsp;percent, or $80&nbsp;million, to $698&nbsp;million, due primarily to the Company's reduced
operating schedule and reductions in the level of food service. Special charges for 2002 included approximately $658&nbsp;million related to aircraft charges, $57&nbsp;million in employee charges
and $3&nbsp;million in facility charges. Special charges for 2001 included approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion related to aircraft charges, $115&nbsp;million in facility charges, $71&nbsp;million
in employee charges and $43&nbsp;million in other charges. U.S. Government grant includes a $10&nbsp;million and $856&nbsp;million benefit recognized for the reimbursement from the U.S.
Government under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act (the Act) for 2002 and
2001, respectively. See a further discussion of special charges and U.S. Government grant in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements. Other operating expenses decreased
12.9&nbsp;percent, or $389&nbsp;million, to $2.6&nbsp;billion, due primarily to decreases in contract maintenance work that American performs for other airlines, and decreases in travel and
incidental costs, advertising and promotion costs, and data processing expenses, which were partially offset by higher insurance and security costs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=30,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=776515,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_30"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2001 Compared to 2000</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's operating expenses increased 17&nbsp;percent, or approximately $3.1&nbsp;billion. However,
excluding TWA LLC's expenses for the period April&nbsp;10, 2001 through December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company's expenses would have increased approximately $888&nbsp;million versus 2000. In
addition to the specific explanations provided below, the significant decline in passenger traffic resulting from the terrorist acts of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and resulting reduced operating
schedule caused a favorable impact on certain passenger-related operating expenses, including aircraft fuel, other rentals and landing fees, commissions to agents and booking and credit card fees, and
food service. American's cost per ASM increased 9.4&nbsp;percent to 11.46 cents, excluding TWA LLC and including the impact of special charges and U.S. Government grant. The increase in American's
cost per ASM was driven partially by a reduction in ASMs&nbsp;due to the Company's More Room Throughout Coach program. Removing the impact of this program, American's cost per ASM grew approximately
6.3&nbsp;percent, excluding TWA LLC and including the impact of special charges and U.S. Government grant. Wages, salaries and benefits increased 18.4&nbsp;percent, or $1.3&nbsp;billion, and
included approximately $920&nbsp;million related to the addition of TWA. The remaining increase of approximately $329&nbsp;million related primarily to an increase in the average number of
equivalent employees and contractual wage rate and seniority increases that are built into the Company's labor contracts. During 2001, the Company recorded approximately $300&nbsp;million in
additional wages, salaries and benefits related primarily to the Company's new contracts with its flight attendants and Transport Workers Union work groups. This was mostly offset by a
$328&nbsp;million decrease in the provision for profit-sharing as compared to 2000. Aircraft fuel expense increased 15.8&nbsp;percent, or $393&nbsp;million, and included approximately
$322&nbsp;million related to the addition of TWA LLC. The remaining increase in aircraft fuel expense was due to a 4.2&nbsp;percent increase in the Company's average price per gallon, partially
offset by a 3.7&nbsp;percent decrease in the Company's fuel consumption, excluding TWA LLC. Depreciation and amortization expense increased 16.8&nbsp;percent, or $202&nbsp;million, due primarily
to the addition of new aircraft and an increase of approximately $88&nbsp;million related to TWA. Commissions to agents and booking and credit card fees decreased 8.6&nbsp;percent, or
$142&nbsp;million, and included approximately $174&nbsp;million related to TWA LLC. The decrease in commissions, booking fees and credit card expense was due primarily to a 13.2&nbsp;percent
decrease in passenger revenues, excluding TWA LLC, and the benefit from commission structure changes implemented in 2000. Other rentals and landing fees increased $198&nbsp;million, or
19.8&nbsp;percent, and included approximately $130&nbsp;million related to the addition of TWA LLC. The remaining increase of $68&nbsp;million was due primarily to higher facilities rent and
landing fees across the Company's system. Aircraft rentals increased $222&nbsp;million, or 36.6&nbsp;percent, due primarily to the addition of TWA LLC aircraft. Other operating expenses increased
11.4&nbsp;percent, or $308&nbsp;million, and included approximately $244&nbsp;million related to TWA LLC. Special charges included approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion related to aircraft charges,
$115&nbsp;million in facility exit costs, $71&nbsp;million in employee charges and $43&nbsp;million in other charges. U.S. Government grant included an $856&nbsp;million benefit recognized for
the reimbursement from the U.S. Government under the Act. See a further discussion of special charges and U.S. Government grant in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>OTHER INCOME (EXPENSE)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Other
income (expense) consists of interest income and expense, interest capitalized and miscellaneous&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2002 Compared to 2001</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased $244&nbsp;million, or 85.3&nbsp;percent, to $530&nbsp;million due primarily to the
following: Interest income decreased $39&nbsp;million, or 35.5&nbsp;percent, to $71&nbsp;million due primarily to decreases in interest rates. Interest expense increased $147&nbsp;million, or
27.3&nbsp;percent, to $685&nbsp;million resulting primarily from the increase in the Company's long-term debt of approximately $2.6&nbsp;billion. Interest capitalized decreased
$58&nbsp;million, or 40.3&nbsp;percent, to $86&nbsp;million due primarily to a decrease in purchase deposits for flight equipment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2001 Compared to 2000</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income decreased $44&nbsp;million, or 28.6&nbsp;percent, resulting from lower investment balances
throughout most of 2001. Interest expense increased $71&nbsp;million, or 15.2&nbsp;percent, resulting primarily from the increase in long-term debt of approximately
$4.2&nbsp;billion. Miscellaneous&#151;net decreased $70&nbsp;million due primarily to Miscellaneous&#151;net in 2001 including a $45&nbsp;million gain from the settlement of a
legal matter related to the Company's 1999 labor disruption, offset by the write-down of certain investments held by the Company. This compares to Miscellaneous-net in 2000
including a $57&nbsp;million gain on the sale of the Company's warrants to purchase 5.5&nbsp;million shares of priceline.com Incorporated (priceline) common stock and a gain of approximately
$41&nbsp;million from the recovery of start-up expenses from the Canadian Airlines International Limited (Canadian) services agreement. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=31,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=915230,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_31"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>INCOME TAX PROVISION (BENEFIT)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>2002</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The effective tax rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was impacted by a $57&nbsp;million charge resulting from a
provision in Congress' economic stimulus package that changes the period for carrybacks of net operating losses (NOLs). This change allows the Company to carry back 2001 and 2002 NOLs for five years,
rather than two years under the previous law, allowing the Company to more quickly recover its NOLs. The extended NOL carryback did however result in the displacement of foreign tax credits taken in
prior years. These credits are now expected to expire before being utilized by the Company, resulting in this charge. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>OPERATING STATISTICS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table provides statistical information for American and AMR Eagle for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>On
April&nbsp;9, 2001, TWA LLC (a wholly owned subsidiary of American) purchased substantially all of the assets and assumed certain liabilities of Trans World Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.
(TWA). Accordingly, the 2001 financial information above includes the operating results of TWA LLC since the date of acquisition. See a further discussion of the TWA acquisition in Note&nbsp;17 to
the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=32,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=215179,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349A.;8',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_32"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Liquidity and Capital Resources</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In response to the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks, the Company initiated the following measures: reduced capacity by approximately 20&nbsp;percent,
grounded aircraft and deferred certain aircraft deliveries to future years, significantly reduced capital spending, closed facilities, reduced its workforce (see Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated
financial statements for additional information) and implemented numerous other cost reduction initiatives. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2002, given, among other things: (i)&nbsp;the steep fall-off in demand for air travel, particularly business travel, caused by the continuing weakness of the U.S.
economy, (ii)&nbsp;reduced pricing power, resulting mainly from greater cost sensitivity on the part of travelers, especially business travelers, and increasing competition from low cost carriers,
and (iii)&nbsp;the residual effects of September&nbsp;11, the Company announced a series of initiatives to further reduce its costs, simplify its aircraft fleet, and enhance productivity. These
initiatives included, among other things, de-peaking of the Company's Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport hub (following the de-peaking of its Chicago hub); gradually
phasing out operation of its Fokker aircraft fleet; and reducing capacity in the fourth quarter of 2002. In addition, the Company reduced its workforce to better align its workforce with the planned
capacity reductions, fleet simplification, and hub restructurings. Despite the Company's on-going efforts to reduce its costs, many of its costs are attributable to factors largely beyond
the Company's control, including (i)&nbsp;escalating fuel prices, (ii)&nbsp;increased insurance costs and (iii)&nbsp;increased security costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Part&nbsp;A of Item 1, the Company's recent financial results are unsustainable. Given the severity of the Company's financial situation and the Company's belief that a
permanent shift has occurred in the airline revenue environment, the Company continues to review its business model, particularly with a view towards identifying significant cost reductions. The
Company believes that it must quickly reduce its annual operating costs by at least $4&nbsp;billion in order to become competitive and sustain its operations. The Company has made progress in
identifying more than $2&nbsp;billion in annual operating cost reductions via initiatives involving: (i)&nbsp;scheduling efficiencies, including de-peaking certain of its hubs as
referred to above, (ii)&nbsp;fleet simplification, (iii)&nbsp;streamlined customer interaction, (iv)&nbsp;distribution modifications, (v)&nbsp;in-flight product changes,
(vi)&nbsp;operational changes and (vii)&nbsp;headquarters/administration efficiencies. Even with these initiatives, however, a large shortfall of approximately $2&nbsp;billion remains between
identified annual cost reductions and needed cost reductions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February&nbsp;2003, American asked its labor leaders and other employees for approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion in permanent, annual savings through a combination of changes in
wages, benefits and work rules. The requested $1.8&nbsp;billion in savings is divided by work group as follows: $660&nbsp;million&#151;pilots, $620&nbsp;million&#151;Transportation
Workers Union (TWU) represented employees, $340&nbsp;million&#151;flight attendants, $100&nbsp;million&#151;management and support staff, and $80&nbsp;million&#151;agents
and representatives. On March&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company reached agreements with the leaders of the three major unions representing American employees (the Labor Agreements) and announced changes in
pay plans and benefits for non-unionized employees (including officers and other management) which will meet the targeted contributions. Of the approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion in
savings, approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion are to be accomplished through wage and benefit reductions while the remaining approximately $.8&nbsp;billion would be accomplished through changes in work
rules which would result in additional job reductions. Wage reductions became effective on April&nbsp;1, 2003 for officers and will become effective on May&nbsp;1, 2003 for all other employees.
Reductions related to benefits and work rule changes will be phased in over time. In connection with the changes in wages, benefits and work rules, the Labor Agreements provide for the issuance of
approximately 38&nbsp;million shares of AMR stock in the form of stock options which will generally vest over a three year period (see Note&nbsp;11 to the consolidated financial statements for
additional information). Although these Labor Agreements enabled the Company to avoid an immediate filing of a petition for relief under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (a Chapter&nbsp;11
filing), these Labor Agreements must still be ratified by the unions' memberships. At the time of the filing of this Form&nbsp;10-K, the unions have put the Labor Agreements out for a
ratification vote. It is anticipated that the official results of the voting will be formally announced on April&nbsp;15, 2003. A group of pilots filed a lawsuit on April&nbsp;14, 2003 contesting
the union ratification process. The U.S. District Court in Fort Worth, Texas denied the request for a temporary restraining order. Failure of one or more of the unions to ratify its Labor Agreement
would likely lead the Company to initiate a Chapter&nbsp;11 filing. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=33,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=537684,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349B.;14',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_33"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company continues to negotiate concessions from its vendors, lessors and suppliers; however, the Company cannot reliably predict whether it will obtain the necessary
concessions or for what amount. In return for concessions, the Company plans to deliver shares of AMR common stock to its vendors, lessors and other creditors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Even
if the Labor Agreements are ratified and the Company obtains concessions from its vendors, lessors and suppliers, the Company may nonetheless need to initiate a Chapter&nbsp;11
filing because its financial condition will remain weak and its prospects uncertain. The fragility of the Company's financial condition is further illustrated by the going concern opinion of the
Company's independent auditors (see page&nbsp;47). Other negative factors include but are not limited to, the failure of the U. S. economy to soon begin a recovery, a prolonged war in Iraq, another
terrorist attack, the failure of the Company to satisfy the liquidity requirement in certain of its credit agreements, or the inability of the Company to access the capital markets for additional
financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2001 and 2002, the Company raised approximately $8.3&nbsp;billion of funding to finance capital commitments and to fund operating losses. The Company expects that it will
continue to need to raise significant additional financing in the near future to cover its liquidity needs, until such time as the cost initiatives discussed in the previous paragraphs become
effective and the Company returns to profitability. The Company had approximately $2.0&nbsp;billion in unrestricted cash and short-term investments as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. The
Company also had available possible future financing sources, including, but not limited to: (i)&nbsp;a limited amount of additional secured aircraft debt (as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
Company had Section&nbsp;1110 eligible unencumbered aircraft with an estimated market value of approximately $670&nbsp;million), (ii)&nbsp;sale-leaseback transactions of owned
property, including aircraft and real estate, (iii)&nbsp;securitization of future operating receipts, and (iv)&nbsp;the potential sale of certain non-core assets (including the
Company's interests in AMR Investments, as discussed in Item 1 and Worldspan, a computer reservations systems partnership). However, these financing sources may not be available to the Company in
light of its financial condition. To the extent that the Company is unable to access capital markets and raise additional capital, the Company will be unable to fund its obligations and sustain its
operations. In such an event, the Company will be forced to initiate a Chapter 11 filing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April 11-12, 2003, the Senate and House agreed to aviation-related assistance provisions in supplemental appropriations legislation to fund the war in Iraq. The legislation is
expected to be signed by President Bush on April&nbsp;14, 2003. The new law would authorize payment of (i)&nbsp;$100&nbsp;million to compensate air carriers for the direct costs associated with
the strengthening of flight deck doors and locks and (ii)&nbsp;$2.3&nbsp;billion to reimburse air carriers for increased security costs which shall be distributed in proportion to amounts each has
paid or collected as of the date of enactment in passenger security and air carrier security fees to the Transportation Security Administration. In addition, the new law would suspend the collection
of the passenger security fee from June&nbsp;1, 2003 until October&nbsp;1, 2003, and extend war-risk insurance through September&nbsp;30, 2004. The Company is not able to estimate its portion of
this compensation at this time. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2003, as a result of the Company's declining financial condition, the Company has made approximately $500&nbsp;million in fuel prepayments, tax escrow deposits
and credit card holdback deposits. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=34,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=117563,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349B.;14',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_34"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AMR
and American's credit ratings are significantly below investment grade. In June&nbsp;2002, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's downgraded the credit ratings of AMR and American, and the
credit ratings of a number of other major airlines. The long-term credit ratings of AMR and American were removed from Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's CreditWatch with negative implications and
were given a negative outlook. In September&nbsp;2002, Moody's downgraded the unsecured credit ratings of both AMR and American and maintained a negative outlook on these ratings. In
January&nbsp;2003, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's placed the credit ratings of AMR and American on review for downgrade. In February&nbsp;2003, Moody's further downgraded the senior implied
rating for AMR, the senior unsecured ratings of both AMR and American and the ratings of most of American's secured debt. The Moody's ratings remain on review for possible downgrade. Also in
February&nbsp;2003, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's lowered its long-term corporate credit ratings for both AMR and American, lowered the senior secured and unsecured debt ratings of AMR, and
lowered the secured debt rating of American. American's short-term rating was withdrawn. Ratings on most of American's non-enhanced equipment trust certificates were also
lowered. In addition, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's revised the CreditWatch implications to developing from negative. In March&nbsp;2003, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's further lowered its
long-term corporate credit ratings for both AMR and American, lowered the senior secured and unsecured debt ratings of AMR, and lowered the secured debt rating of American. Ratings on most
of American's non-enhanced equipment trust certificates were also lowered. These reductions have increased the Company's borrowing costs. Additional significant reductions in AMR's or
American's credit ratings would further increase its borrowing or other
costs and further restrict the availability of future financing. Also in March&nbsp;2003, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's removed AMR's common stock from the S&amp;P 500 index. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;American
has a fully drawn $834&nbsp;million credit facility that expires December&nbsp;15, 2005. On March&nbsp;31, 2003, American and certain lenders in such facility entered into
a waiver and amendment that (i)&nbsp;waived, until May&nbsp;15, 2003, the requirement that American pledge additional collateral to the extent the value of the existing collateral was insufficient
under the terms of the facility, (ii)&nbsp;waived American's liquidity covenant for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, and (iii)&nbsp;modified the financial covenants applicable to
subsequent periods and increased the applicable margin for advances under the facility. On May&nbsp;15, 2003, American expects to be required to pledge an additional 30
(non-Section&nbsp;1110 eligible) aircraft having an aggregate net book value as of March&nbsp;31, 2003 of approximately $451&nbsp;million. Pursuant to the modified financial
covenants, American is required to maintain at least $1.0&nbsp;billion of liquidity, consisting of unencumbered cash and short-term investments for the second quarter 2003 and beyond. At
this point, it is uncertain whether the Company will be able to satisfy this liquidity requirement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the required ratio of EBITDAR to fixed charges has been decreased until the period ending December&nbsp;31, 2004, and the next test of such cash flow coverage ratio will
not occur until March&nbsp;31, 2004. The amendment also provided for a 50 basis points increase in the applicable margin over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR), resulting in an effective
interest rate (as of March&nbsp;31, 2003) of 4.73&nbsp;percent. The interest rate will be reset again on September&nbsp;17, 2003. At American's option, interest on the facility can be calculated
on one of several different bases. For most borrowings, American would anticipate choosing a floating rate based upon LIBOR. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company had $783&nbsp;million in restricted cash and short-term investments as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. These restricted assets relate primarily to collateral held
to support standby letters of credit backing floating rate tax-exempt bonds, projected workers' compensation obligations and various other obligations. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
collateral required to support the standby letters of credit backing the floating rate tax-exempt bonds exceeded the face value of the bonds. In the first quarter of 2003, the Company
redeemed all $339&nbsp;million of tax-exempt bonds that were backed by standby letters of credit secured by restricted cash and short-term investments. The redemption of
these bonds resulted in an increase in the Company's unrestricted cash and short-term investments balances in 2003. See Note&nbsp;5 to the consolidated financial statements for
additional information regarding restricted cash and short-term investments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash used by operating activities in 2002 was $1.1&nbsp;billion, compared to net cash provided by operating activities of $542&nbsp;million and $3.1&nbsp;billion in 2001 and
2000, respectively. The $1.7&nbsp;billion decrease from 2001 to 2002 resulted primarily from an increase in the Company's net loss. Included in net cash used by operating activities of 2002 was
approximately $658&nbsp;million received by the Company as a result of the utilization of its 2001 NOL's. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=12,SEQ=35,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=911307,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349B.;14',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_35"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital
expenditures in 2002 totaled $1.9&nbsp;billion, compared to $3.6&nbsp;billion in 2001 and $3.7&nbsp;billion in 2000. In 2002, American took delivery of three Boeing
777-200ERs and seven Boeing 757-200s. AMR Eagle took delivery of 28 Embraer 140s and seven Bombardier CRJ-700 aircraft. These expenditures were financed primarily
through secured mortgage and debt agreements. Proceeds from the sale of equipment and property and other investments totaled $220&nbsp;million, including the proceeds received upon the delivery of
three McDonnell Douglas MD-11 aircraft to FedEx. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;9, 2001, TWA LLC purchased substantially all of the assets and assumed certain liabilities of TWA for approximately $742&nbsp;million, which was funded from the
Company's existing cash and short-term investments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, American issued $617&nbsp;million of enhanced equipment trust certificates secured by aircraft, with interest based on LIBOR plus a spread (0.62&nbsp;percent) and
maturities over various periods, with a final maturity in 2007. These obligations are insured by a third party. A $1&nbsp;billion credit facility, established in late 2001 to serve as an immediate
alternative for this financing, expired undrawn on September&nbsp;30, 2002. Also during 2002, the Company entered into approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion of various debt agreements secured by
aircraft. Effective rates on these agreements are fixed or variable based on LIBOR plus a spread and mature over various periods of time through 2017. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the effective
interest rates on these debt agreements and the enhanced equipment trust certificates described above ranged up to 5.94&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2002, the Regional Airports Improvement Corporation and the New York City Industrial Development Agency issued facilities sublease revenue bonds at the Los Angeles International
Airport and John F. Kennedy International Airport, respectively, to provide reimbursement to American for certain facility construction and other related costs. The Company has recorded the total
amount of the issuances of $759&nbsp;million (net of $38&nbsp;million discount) as long-term debt on the consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. These obligations
bear interest at fixed rates, with an average effective rate of 8.54&nbsp;percent, and mature over various periods of time, with a final maturity in 2028. The Company has received approximately
$672&nbsp;million in reimbursements of certain facility construction and other related costs through December&nbsp;31, 2002. Of the remaining $87&nbsp;million of bond issuance proceeds not yet
received, classified as Other assets on the consolidated balance sheet, $40&nbsp;million are held by the trustee for reimbursement of future facility construction costs and will be available to the
Company in the future, and $47&nbsp;million are held in a debt service reserve fund. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had commitments to acquire the following aircraft: two Boeing 777-200 ERs, nine Boeing 767-300ERs, 22 Embraer regional
jets and 10 Bombardier CRJ-700s in 2003; an aggregate of 74 Embraer regional jets and seven Bombardier CRJ-700s in 2004 through 2006; and an aggregate of 47 Boeing
737-800s and nine Boeing 777-200ERs in 2006 through 2010. Future payments for all aircraft, including the estimated amounts for price escalation, will approximate
$1.0&nbsp;billion in 2003, $753&nbsp;million in 2004, $694&nbsp;million in 2005 and an aggregate of approximately $2.6&nbsp;billion in 2006 through 2010. These commitments and cash flows
reflect agreements the Company entered into with Boeing in November&nbsp;2002 to defer 34 of its 2003 through 2005 deliveries to 2007 and beyond. In addition to these deferrals, Boeing Capital
Corporation has agreed to provide backstop financing for all Boeing aircraft deliveries in 2003. In return, American has agreed to grant Boeing a security interest in certain advance payments
previously made and in certain rights under the aircraft purchase agreement between American and Boeing. In addition, the Company has pre-arranged financing or backstop financing for all
of its 2003 Embraer and Bombardier aircraft deliveries and a portion of its post 2003 deliveries. As a result, substantially all of the aircraft spending in 2003 is supported by committed financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to these commitments for aircraft, the Company expects to spend approximately $400&nbsp;million in 2003 for modifications to aircraft, renovations of&#151;and
additions to&#151;airport and off-airport facilities, and the acquisition of various other equipment and assets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=36,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=280810,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349B.;14',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_36"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has contracted with two regional airlines, Chautauqua Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. (Chautauqua) and Trans States Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. (collectively the AmericanConnection carriers)
to provide Embraer EMB-140/145 regional jet services under the brand "AmericanConnection". Under these arrangements, the Company pays the AmericanConnection carriers a fixed fee per block
hour to operate the aircraft. The block hour fees are designed to cover the AmericanConnection carriers' fully allocated costs. Assumptions for highly volatile or uncontrollable costs such as fuel,
landing fees, insurance, and aircraft ownership are trued up to actual values on a pass through basis. In addition to covering the cost of operations, the Company also pays a designed profit margin to
the AmericanConnection carriers. In consideration for these payments, the Company retains all passenger and other revenues resulting from the operation of the AmericanConnection regional jets. Minimum
payments under the contracts are $124&nbsp;million in 2003, $69&nbsp;million in 2004, $70&nbsp;million in 2005 and $64&nbsp;million in 2006. However, based on expected utilization, the Company
expects to make payments of $164&nbsp;million in 2003, $191&nbsp;million in 2004, $192&nbsp;million in 2005, $194&nbsp;million in 2006 and $195&nbsp;million in 2007. In addition, if the
Company terminates the Chautauqua contract without cause, Chautauqua has the right to put its Embraer aircraft to the Company. If the Company were to terminate the Chautauqua contract without cause
and Chautauqua were to exercise its put rights, the Company would take possession of the aircraft and become liable for lease obligations totaling approximately $21&nbsp;million per year with lease
expirations in 2018 and 2019. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
lessors under two of the Company's aircraft leases have exercised options that require the Company to purchase the related aircraft. Under the terms of the exercised put options, on
or about May&nbsp;27, 2003, the Company will be required to pay approximately $19&nbsp;million to purchase the two aircraft subject to such leases. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is a party to many routine contracts in which it provides general indemnities in the normal course of business to third parties for various risks. The Company has not
recorded a liability for any of these indemnities, as the likelihood of payment in each case is considered remote. These indemnities are discussed in the following paragraphs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's loan agreements and other LIBOR-based financing transactions (including certain leveraged aircraft leases) generally obligate the Company to reimburse the applicable lender
for incremental increased costs due to a change in law that imposes (i)&nbsp;any reserve or special deposit requirement against assets of, deposits with, or credit extended by such lender related to
the loan, (ii)&nbsp;any tax, duty, or other charge with respect to the loan (except standard income tax) or (iii)&nbsp;capital adequacy requirements. In addition, the Company's loan agreements,
derivative transactions and other financing arrangements typically contain a withholding tax provision that requires the Company to pay additional amounts to the applicable lender or other financing
party, generally if withholding taxes are imposed on such lender or other financing party as a result of a change in the applicable tax law. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These
increased cost and withholding tax provisions continue for the entire term of the applicable transaction, and there is no limitation on the maximum additional amounts the Company
could be obligated to pay under such provisions. Any failure to pay amounts due under such provisions generally would trigger an event of default, and, in a secured financing transaction, would
entitle the lender to foreclose upon the collateral to realize the amount due. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has general indemnity clauses in many of its airport and other real estate leases where the Company as lessee indemnifies the lessor (and related parties) against liabilities
related to the Company's use of the leased property. Generally, these indemnifications cover liabilities resulting from the negligence of the indemnified parties, but not liabilities resulting from
the gross negligence or willful misconduct of the
indemnified parties. In addition, the Company provides environmental indemnities in many of these leases for contamination related to the Company's use of the leased property. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
certain transactions, including certain aircraft financing leases and loans and derivative transactions, the lessors, lenders and/or other parties have rights to terminate the
transaction based on changes in foreign tax law, illegality or certain other events or circumstances. In such a case, the Company may be required to make a lump sum payment to terminate the relevant
transaction. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=14,SEQ=37,EFW="2108197",CP="AMR CORP.",DN="1",CHK=898738,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK014:[03DFW9.03DFW1349]DG1349B.;14',USER='LHOUSE',CD='14-APR-2003;20:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1349_1_37"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, in its aircraft financing agreements, the Company generally indemnifies the financing parties, trustees acting on their behalf and other related parties against liabilities
(including certain taxes) resulting from the financing, manufacture, design, ownership, operation and maintenance of the aircraft regardless of whether these liabilities (or taxes) relate to the
negligence of the indemnified parties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is not able to estimate the potential amount of any liability resulting from the indemnities discussed above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
certain contracts with third parties, the Company indemnifies the third party against legal liability arising out of an action by the third party, or certain other parties. The
terms of these contracts vary and the potential exposure under these indemnities cannot be determined. Generally, the Company has liability insurance protecting the Company for its obligations it has
undertaken under these indemnities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes the Company's obligations and commitments as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, to be paid in 2003 through 2007 (in millions): </FONT></P>
